column1: Jalajala (Tagalog pronunciation: [hälɐ̞ˈhalɐ]; also spelled as Jala-jala)
column2: officially the Municipality of Jalajala (Tagalog: Bayan ng Jalajala)
column3: is a 4th class municipality in the province of Rizal

column1: What is now the town's Barangay Punta was the seat of an earlier settlement later known as Halaán. During the summer from April to May
column2: the shores of Laguna de Bay along Punta would be filled with small shellfish locally known as halaán.

column1: As is typical with many modern Philippine toponyms
column2: the town's name supposedly resulted from miscommunication between early Spanish visitors and natives. The Spaniards enquired of some natives along the shoreline
column3: "¿Como se llama este sitio?" ("What is the name of this place?") to which the latter replied
column5:
thinking that the foreigners referred to the shells. The Spaniards accepted the response as the name of the place, and began calling it halaán, later corrupting it into Jalajala.
Another folk etymology is that Jalajala stems from an endemic breed of boar called berk jala, which is abundant in the wilds around the town and is depicted on its seal. As with the other story, a Spaniard asked the Tagalog-speaking natives the place's name, and the locals' interjection of hala-hala” (possibly a hunting chant) was taken by the Spaniards to be their answer.

column1: Jalajala is on a peninsula located 75 kilometres (47 mi) southeast of Manila in the largest freshwater lake in the Philippines
column2: Laguna de Bay. It lies on the eastern part of the Rizal Province and has a land area of 4
column3: 930.000 hectares representing 3.77% of the total land area of the province. Jalajala’s political boundary on the north is the Panguil River
column4: wherein it shares the boundary with the town of Pakil in Laguna. On its southern
column6: and western boundaries lies the Laguna de Bay.

column1: Mount Sembrano forms the boundary of Jalajala and Pililla.
